metadata.title: Java Assessment
metadata.description: Evaluate your Java proficiency with 20 multiple-choice questions covering fundamentals, OOP, collections, and best practices.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a valid access modifier in Java?
questions.explanation: 'package' is not a valid access modifier. Java has four access levels: public, private, protected, and default (no keyword, also called package-private).

questions.text: What is the default value of a boolean variable in Java?
questions.explanation: Boolean instance variables default to 'false' in Java. Only object references default to null; primitive types have their own defaults.

questions.text: Which keyword is used to inherit a class in Java?
questions.explanation: 'extends' is used for class inheritance. 'implements' is for interfaces. 'super' refers to the parent class, and 'inherits' isn't a Java keyword.

questions.text: Which collection class provides fast access by key in Java?
questions.explanation: HashMap provides O(1) average case access by key using hashing. ArrayList and LinkedList use indices, while TreeSet maintains sorted order.

questions.text: What is the output of: System.out.println(5 + 3 + "2");
questions.explanation: Java evaluates left to right. 5+3=8 (integer addition), then 8+"2"="82" (string concatenation when a String is encountered).

questions.text: Which keyword prevents a method from being overridden?
questions.explanation: 'final' prevents method overriding and class extension. 'const' is not a Java keyword (use 'final' for constants).

questions.text: What is the purpose of the 'super' keyword?

options.text: To call the current class constructor
To refer to the parent class

questions.explanation: 'super' refers to the parent class, allowing access to parent methods, constructors, and variables. Use 'this' for the current class.

questions.text: Which interface must be implemented for a class to be used in a for-each loop?
questions.explanation: For-each loops require the Iterable interface, which provides an Iterator for traversing elements. Arrays also work with for-each natively.

questions.text: What is the difference between '==' and '.equals()' in Java?

options.text: '==' checks reference equality, '.equals()' checks value equality

questions.explanation: == compares object references (memory addresses), while .equals() compares values when properly overridden. For Strings, always use .equals().

questions.text: Which exception is thrown when dividing by zero in Java?
questions.explanation: ArithmeticException is thrown for integer division by zero. Note: floating-point division by zero returns Infinity instead of throwing an exception.

questions.text: What is the main difference between an abstract class and an interface?

options.text: Abstract classes can have constructors, interfaces cannot

questions.explanation: Abstract classes can have constructors, instance variables, and implemented methods. Interfaces traditionally only had abstract methods (though Java 8+ added default methods).

questions.text: Which keyword is used to prevent a class from being inherited?
questions.explanation: A 'final' class cannot be extended/inherited. 'sealed' (Java 17+) allows limited inheritance to specific classes.

questions.text: What is autoboxing in Java?

options.text: Automatic conversion of primitive to wrapper class

questions.explanation: Autoboxing automatically converts primitives (int, boolean, etc.) to their wrapper classes (Integer, Boolean, etc.). The reverse is called unboxing.

questions.text: Which collection does NOT allow duplicate elements?
questions.explanation: HashSet implements the Set interface which prohibits duplicates. ArrayList, LinkedList, and Vector all allow duplicate elements.

questions.text: What is the purpose of the 'static' keyword?

options.text: Belongs to the class rather than instances

questions.explanation: Static members belong to the class itself, not individual instances. They're shared across all objects and can be accessed without creating an instance.

questions.text: Which method is called when an object is garbage collected?
questions.explanation: finalize() is called before garbage collection (deprecated since Java 9). Use try-with-resources or explicit cleanup instead.

questions.text: What is method overloading?

options.text: Same method name with different parameters

questions.explanation: Overloading = same method name with different parameters (compile-time polymorphism). Overriding = redefining a parent class method (runtime polymorphism).

questions.text: Which of these is a checked exception in Java?
questions.explanation: IOException is a checked exception (must be handled or declared). RuntimeExceptions like NullPointerException and ArithmeticException are unchecked.

questions.text: What does the 'transient' keyword do?

options.text: Prevents a variable from being serialized

questions.explanation: 'transient' excludes a field from serialization. Useful for sensitive data (passwords) or fields that can be reconstructed.

questions.text: What is the time complexity of searching in an unsorted ArrayList?
questions.explanation: Linear search through an unsorted ArrayList requires checking each element: O(n). Sorted lists can use binary search for O(log n) complexity.

tiers.title: Java Expert
tiers.message: Outstanding performance! You have a strong grasp of Java fundamentals, OOP principles, collections, and best practices. You're well-prepared for Java-based coding interviews.

tiers.title: Strong Java Skills
tiers.message: Well done! You have a solid understanding of Java. Review the questions you missed to strengthen your knowledge further, especially around collections and advanced OOP concepts.

tiers.title: Intermediate Level
tiers.message: You have a decent foundation in Java. Focus on practicing more with collections, exception handling, and OOP concepts to improve your skills.

tiers.title: Beginner Level
tiers.message: You're making progress! Spend more time studying Java basics, OOP principles, and the Collections framework. Practice coding daily to build your skills.

tiers.title: Need More Practice
tiers.message: Consider starting with Java fundamentals. Work through beginner tutorials covering OOP, data types, and basic syntax. Practice coding regularly to build your foundation.
